awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Ergodic Control of Stochastic Differential Equations Driven By a Class of Pure-Jump Levy Processes, and Applications to Stochastic Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Queueing processes in large-scale networks are ubiquitous in society as exemplified by patient flow in hospitals, telephone call centers, service networks, and manufacturing and service operations management. This research will provide fundamental theoretical understanding of these queueing processes in the presence of batch arrivals. The results of this research will be put into direct applications to real-world stochastic networks through collaborations with the health systems and system analysis industry. This research will support under-represented minority groups and train young STEM graduates with new mathematical skills.
  
This research concerns ergodic control problems for systems described by Ito stochastic differential equations (SDEs) driven by pure-jump Levy processes. The research objectives are: (1) to develop a comprehensive theoretical framework for ergodic control for a large class of controlled SDEs driven by a pure-jump Levy process; (2) to study a novel fully nonlinear problem that arises in admission control and falls outside the usual paradigm of stochastic control; and (3) to develop value iteration algorithms and spatial approximation methods in order to study large time asymptotics, and also to facilitate the numerical solution of the associated Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equations, and the design of learning schemes for adaptive control in the presence of unknown parameters. This research will advance the basic science of applied mathematics and stochastic control, and make fundamental contributions to applied probability and stochastic networks.

por.por_cntn:
This research has produced ground-breaking methodologies and transformative techniques to study ergodic control problems for a broad class of SDEs with jumps which includes those arising in the study of stochastic networks in heavy traffic. The analytical tools developed has solved important open problems in ergodic control for these models. Ergodic control on non-finite state spaces often requires structural assumptions which amount to either a blanket stochastic stability hypothesis, or certain growth conditions on the running cost or utility function. Since  structural assumptions are not met for the models encountered in parallel server networks. At the same time, Hamilton--Jacobi--Bellman (HJB) theory for SDEs driven by a pure-jump process is very underdeveloped, primarily due to the non-local nature of the infinitesimal generator. This research has developed the ergodic control theory for SDEs driven by a pure-jump process in a way that it parallels what is currently known for controlled diffusions. This includes establishing existence and uniqueness of solutions to the ergodic HJB equations with non-local operators, stochastic representations of these solutions, and verification of optimality. This research has also studied the large time asymptotics of the finite-horizon optimal control problem, which from the analytical viewpoint concerns the stabilization of a quasilinear Cauchy problem for a non-local parabolic equation.

This research funded by this grant has direct implications for applications in telecommunications, data centers, manufacturing and service systems where the demand process is facing a lot of uncertainty, in particular, bursty and heavy-tailed. It has also produced original results in analysis which are of interest to the PDE community. In addition, this grant has funded well STEM-trained graduates with new mathematical and engineering tools and new industrial application frontiers.
